verses.text: He that is merciful will lend unto \add his\add* neighbour; And he that strengtheneth his hand keepeth the commandments.
Lend to \add thy\add* neighbour in time of his need, And pay thou \add thy\add* neighbour again in due season.
Keep thy word, and deal faithfully with him, And thou shalt always find the thing that is necessary for thee.
Many, when a thing was lent \add them\add*, reckoned \add it\add* to be found, And put them to trouble that helped them.

Till he hath received, he will kiss a man’s hand; And for \add his\add* neighbour’s money he will speak submissly: But when \add he\add* should repay, he will prolong the time, And return words of grief, And complain of the time.

If he prevail, he shall hardly receive the half, And he will count as if he had found it: If not, he hath deprived him of his money, And he hath gotten him an enemy without cause: He payeth him with cursings and railings; And for honour he will pay him disgrace.
Many therefore have refused \add to lend\add* for \add other men’s\add* ill dealing, Fearing to be defrauded.
Yet have thou patience with a \add man\add* in poor estate, And delay not to shew him mercy.
Help the poor for the commandment’s sake, And turn him not away because of his poverty.
Lose \add thy\add* money for \add thy\add* brother and \add thy\add* friend, And let it not rust under a stone to be lost.
Lay up thy treasure according to the commandments of the most High, And it shall bring thee more profit than gold.
Shut up alms in thy storehouses: And it shall deliver thee from all affliction.
It shall fight for thee against \add thine\add* enemies Better than a mighty shield and strong spear.
An honest man is surety for \add his\add* neighbour: But he that is impudent will forsake him.
Forget not the friendship of \add thy\add* surety, For he hath given his life for thee.
A sinner will overthrow the good \add estate\add* of \add his\add* surety:
And he that is of an unthankful mind will leave him \add in danger\add* that delivered \add him\add*.
Suretiship hath undone many of good estate, And shaked them as a wave of the sea: Mighty men hath it driven from their houses, So that they wandered among strange nations.
A wicked \add man\add* transgressing the commandments of the Lord shall fall into suretiship: And he that \add undertaketh and\add* followeth other men’s business for gain shall fall into suits.
Help \add thy\add* neighbour according to thy power, And beware that thou thyself fall not \add into the same\add*.
The chief thing for life \add is\add* water, and bread, And clothing, and a house to cover shame.
Better \add is\add* the life of a poor \add man\add* in a mean cottage, Than delicate fare in another man’s \add house\add*.
Be it little or much, hold thee contented, That thou hear not the reproach of thy house.
\add For it is\add* a miserable life \add to go\add* from house to house: For where thou art a stranger, thou darest not open thy mouth.
Thou shalt entertain, and feast, and have no thanks: Moreover, thou shalt hear bitter \add words:\add*
Come, \add thou\add* stranger, \add and\add* furnish a table, And feed me \add of\add* that thou hast ready.
Give place, \add thou\add* stranger, to an honourable \add man;\add* My brother cometh to be lodged, \add and I have\add* need of \add mine\add* house.
These \add things are\add* grievous to a man of understanding; The upbraiding of houseroom, and reproaching of the lender.
